author: Stephanie Mlot
title: NASA Engineer Joins Uber's Flying Car Initiative
text:
Uber A Jetsons future may be closer than you think: Uber reportedly hired a veteran NASA engineer to develop flying cars.
After more than three decades with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Mark Moore is taking his Vertical Take-off and Landing (VTOL) expertise to Uber.
According to Bloomberg , Moore will step into the new position of director of engineering for aviation, tackling the ride-hailing firm’s flying car initiative, “Uber Elevate.”
The app-based car service in September talked up vertical take-off and landing technology; a month later it released a 97-page document detailing its plan for an urban VTOL network that “will likely have significant cost advantages over heavy-infrastructure approaches such as roads, rail, bridges, and tunnels.”
Moore is listed as one of more than a dozen contributors and reviewers of the paper, written by Uber’s Chief Product Officer Jeff Holden and Uber Elevate Product Manager Nikhil Goel.
“Uber continues to see its role as an accelerant-catalyst to the entire ecosystem, and we are excited to have Mark joining us to work with manufacturers and stakeholders as we continue to explore the use case described in our whitepaper,” Goel said in a statement to Bloomberg.
Moore’s LinkedIn profile still suggests he’s working as chief technologist for on-demand mobility at NASA’s Langley Research Center. But updating social media accounts after landing a new job is probably not high on the engineer’s to-do list.
Uber did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Still a sci-fi fantasy, flying cars may one day escape movie screens and book pages to make real-life daily commute more efficient.
Based on Uber’s vision of the future, folks will hitch a ride in one of its branded cars (self-driving or otherwise) to the local “vertiport,” where air-taxi passengers take off and land on their way to the office or home. The technology aims to reduce vehicle noise and emissions while increasing autonomy.
“A network of small, electric aircraft that take off and land vertically … will enable rapid, reliable transportation between suburbs and cities and, ultimately, within cities,” the Uber paper said.
